Question.content: A commercially available conc. H₂SO₄ acid contains 95% H₂SO₄ by mass, has a density of 1.84g/ml and relative molar mass of 98g/mol. Calculate: (a) Molarity (b) Pure mass of H₂SO₄ in 1L solution (c) Volume of conc. acid needed to prepare 0.15M H₂SO₄ in 250ml.

Explanation.content:
Detailed Solution

(a) Molarity Calculation

Given:

  • Percentage by mass = 95% H₂SO₄
  • Density (ρ) = 1.84 g/mL
  • Molar mass (M) = 98 g/mol

Step 1: Calculate mass of 1L solution

\(\text{Mass}_{\text{solution}} = \rho \times V = 1.84\,\text{g/mL} \times 1000\,\text{mL} = 1840\,\text{g}\)

Step 2: Determine mass of pure H₂SO₄

\(\text{Mass}_{\text{H₂SO₄}} = 0.95 \times 1840\,\text{g} = 1748\,\text{g}\)

Step 3: Calculate moles of H₂SO₄

\(n = \frac{\text{Mass}}{\text{Molar mass}} = \frac{1748\,\text{g}}{98\,\text{g/mol}} \approx 17.836\,\text{moles}\)

Step 4: Determine molarity

\(\text{Molarity} = \frac{n}{V} = \frac{17.836\,\text{mol}}{1\,\text{L}} = 17.836\,\text{M}\)

Final Answer: 17.83 M (rounded to 2 decimal places)

(b) Pure Mass of H₂SO₄ in 1L Solution

From part (a) Step 2, we already calculated this value:

\(\boxed{1748\,\text{grams}}\)

This means there are 1748 grams of pure H₂SO₄ in every liter of the concentrated solution.

(c) Volume Needed for Dilution

We use the dilution formula:

\(M_1V_1 = M_2V_2\)

Where:

  • \(M_1 = 17.836\,\text{M}\) (concentrated solution)
  • \(V_1 = ?\) (volume we need to find)
  • \(M_2 = 0.15\,\text{M}\) (desired concentration)
  • \(V_2 = 250\,\text{mL}\) (desired volume)

Rearranging the formula:

\(V_1 = \frac{M_2V_2}{M_1} = \frac{0.15\,\text{M} \times 250\,\text{mL}}{17.836\,\text{M}} \approx 2.102\,\text{mL}\)

Important Safety Note: Always add concentrated acid to water slowly while stirring to prevent violent reactions and heat generation.

Final Answer: 2.10 mL (rounded to 2 decimal places)

Question.content: (a) How many milliliters of 24.0% (W/V) Na₂CO₃ solution is required to prepare 3.60% (W/V) Na₂CO₃ in 1L solution? (b) Meaning of 'TC 20°C' on glassware (c) Best desiccants for (i) Organic solids (ii) Inorganic solids.

Answer.content: (a) 150ml (b) Calibrated for 20°C (c)(i) Silica gel (ii) Calcium chloride

Explanation.content:
(a) Dilution Calculation

Given: C₁=24% (W/V), C₂=3.6% (W/V), V₂=1000mL

Formula: \(C_1V_1 = C_2V_2\) → \(24\% \times V_1 = 3.6\% \times 1000\text{mL}\)

Calculation: \(V_1 = \frac{3.6 \times 1000}{24} = \boxed{150\text{mL}}\)

(b) TC 20°C Meaning

"TC" = To Contain, "20°C" = calibration temperature

  • Glassware volume markings are accurate at 20°C (standard lab condition)
  • Thermal expansion affects volume measurements at other temperatures

(c) Desiccants

Material TypeBest DesiccantMechanism
Organic SolidsSilica gelPhysical adsorption (non-reactive)
Inorganic SolidsCalcium chlorideForms hydrates (CaCl₂·nH₂O)

Question.content: (a) Explain '(3:4) HNO₃, 420ml aqueous solution'. (b) Volume constituents of this solution. (c) Two reasons for using Aluminum paints in labs.

Answer.content: (a) 3 parts HNO₃ to 4 parts water (b) 180ml HNO₃ + 240ml water (c) Corrosion resistance, heat reflection

Explanation.content:
(a) Ratio Notation

\(\left(3:4\right)\) HNO₃ means:

  • 3 volumes concentrated nitric acid (≈16M)
  • 4 volumes distilled water
  • Total solution volume = 420mL

(b) Volume Calculation

Total parts: \(3 + 4 = 7\)

Volume per part: \(\frac{420\text{mL}}{7} = 60\text{mL}\)

HNO₃ volume: \(3 \times 60\text{mL} = \boxed{180\text{mL}}\)

Water volume: \(4 \times 60\text{mL} = \boxed{240\text{mL}}\)

(c) Aluminum Paint Benefits

  1. Corrosion Resistance: Forms Al₂O₃ oxide layer that protects against chemical attack
  2. Thermal Reflectivity: Reflects \(\gt90\%\) of infrared radiation, keeping equipment cooler

Question.content: (a) 0.24g NaCl in 50ml solution: Find (i) Molarity (ii) mg/ml concentration. (b) Function of constant-level device (c) Lab equipment with this device (d) Functions of (i) Lab policeman (ii) Lab thief.

Answer.content: (a)(i) 0.082M (ii) 4.8mg/ml (b) Maintains liquid level (c) Steam bath (d)(i) Mixes/stirs (ii) Retrieves samples

Explanation.content:
(a) Solution Preparation

(i) Molarity Calculation:

\(\text{Moles NaCl} = \frac{0.24\text{g}}{58.44\text{g/mol}} = 0.004107\text{mol}\)

\(\text{Molarity} = \frac{0.004107\text{mol}}{0.05\text{L}} = \boxed{0.0821\text{M}}\)

(ii) Mass Concentration:

\(\frac{240\text{mg}}{50\text{mL}} = \boxed{4.8\text{mg/mL}}\)

(b) Constant-Level Device

Maintains consistent liquid level via:

  • Overflow mechanism
  • Float valve system
  • Prevents evaporation loss in heated baths

(c) Example Equipment

Steam Bath features:

  • Temperature range: 40-100°C
  • Uses water or oil as heat transfer medium
  • Constant-level ensures safe evaporation rates
